Sure you can! However, we can only let you try a very small part of DOCK6. But don't worry! It's still very cool! If you want the full version, please obtain a DOCK6 license shown in the navigation bar at the top or click on the button at the right.

The method we will be learning is pose reproduction!

Obtain License

Pose Reproduction

Pose reproduction is a computational drug design technique, where users could try to predict the pose of a ligand that was previously crystallized in a protein system.

Generally, scientists use a protein database to source those protein systems. A viewing of such systems could be open with Chimera. At the image at the left is a streptavidin protein structure crystallized with a synthetic azobenzene ligand. Strangely, there are two subprotein structures that seem like they are mirror images of each other. This is normal! Protein crystallographey software will create mirror images of a monomeric protein!

After scientists study the structure, they would isolate the crystallized ligand and protein seperately and create a molecular file for each (DOCK6 takes in .mol2 file format). Molecular visualization softwares like Chimera are capable of carefully handling each object of the system so you can create these chemical file formats. After the isolation process, each file format will be prepped for docking. Remember, these structures are not charged and protonated because PDB protein systems will have neither.

DOCK6 is developed by the Rizzo Group.

Hexagon abstract vector created by starline - www.freepik.com
